subject: Re: [junit] a test framework to codify levelizaton?
msgSnippet: ... Very likely too trivial for that. When I have the book in my hot sticky hands I shall give it a jolly good read. ... My brace-style predates Python. (You d
messageBody:
On Monday 19 July 2004 15:47, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Chris Dollin wrote:
> > Some of the tests are more multi-facteted than I'd really like, such as:
> >
> > public void testRemove()
> > {
> > testRemove( "S ?? ??", "S ?? ??" );
> > testRemove( "S ?? ??", "?? P ??" );
> > testRemove( "S ?? ??", "?? ?? O" );
> > testRemove( "?? P ??", "S ?? ??" );
> > testRemove( "?? P ??", "?? P ??" );
> > testRemove( "?? P ??", "?? ?? O" );
> > testRemove( "?? ?? O", "S ?? ??" );
> > testRemove( "?? ?? O", "?? P ??" );
> > testRemove( "?? ?? O", "?? ?? O" );
> > }
> >
> > which is really nine tests, but the tedium of writing a separate test
> > method for each overwhelmed me, and they are linked. Hmm.
>
> Sounds like a Parameterized Test Case. (Recipe 4.8) :)

Very likely too trivial for that. When I have the book in my hot sticky
hands I shall give it a jolly good read.

> > Always worth revisiting code ...
>
> Indeed. The only impenetrable bit for me is the placement of the
> braces.... Python, anyone? :)

My brace-style predates Python. (You'd probably hate my more recent
experimental style even more

public void testRemove( String findRemove, String findCheck )
{ Graph g = getGraphWith( "S P O" );
ExtendedIterator it = g.find( Triple.create( findRemove ) );
try
{ it.next(); it.remove();
ExtendedIterator ut = g.find( Triple.create( findCheck ) );
assertFalse( ut.hasNext() ); }
catch (UnsupportedOperationException e)
{ assertFalse( g.getCapabilities().iteratorRemoveAllowed() ); } }

I suspect it would melt my colleague's brains, so I'm reticent to go full-bore
on it.)

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
